questions.question: How many nucleotides make up one codon?
questions.explanation: A codon is a three-nucleotide sequence on mRNA that specifies one amino acid. This triplet system allows 64 possible combinations.

questions.question: Which codon signals the start of protein synthesis?
questions.explanation: AUG codes for methionine and serves as the start codon in almost all organisms. It marks where translation begins.

questions.question: What does it mean that the genetic code is redundant?
options: Multiple codons can specify the same amino acid
One codon specifies and can specify many amino acids
questions.explanation: Redundancy means most amino acids are specified by more than one codon. For example, leucine has six different codons.

questions.question: Which statement about stop codons is correct?
options: They signal the end of translation
They code for special amino acids
They are read but not used
questions.explanation: Stop codons (UAA, UAG, UGA) signal the ribosome to release the polypeptide chain. They do not code for any amino acid.

questions.question: The genetic code is nearly universal. What does this mean?
options: Most organisms use the same codon assignments
All codons work the same in every cell
questions.explanation: With minor exceptions, the same codons specify the same amino acids across nearly all life forms, suggesting a common evolutionary origin.

questions.question: Which best describes how codons are read?
options: Without gaps, from a fixed start point
questions.explanation: The reading frame is set by the start codon, and ribosomes read mRNA continuously in non-overlapping triplets until a stop codon.

questions.question: If a codon sequence is GCA, what will it likely code for?
questions.explanation: Using the genetic code: GCA, GCC, GCG, and GCU all code for alanine. GCA is one of them.

questions.question: What would happen if a codon mutates from UUU to UUC?
options: No change in the amino acid
A different amino acid is inserted
questions.explanation: Both UUU and UUC code for phenylalanine. This is a silent mutationâ€”the DNA changes but the protein does not.

questions.question: How does the ribosome identify the correct tRNA?
options: By reading the amino acid directly
By chemical tags on the tRNA
questions.explanation: The ribosome ensures correct pairing between mRNA codon and tRNA anticodon. This ensures the right amino acid is added.

questions.question: Why is the genetic code described as unambiguous?
options: Each codon specifies only one amino acid
It never makes mistakes during translation
It cannot be changed by mutations
questions.explanation: Unambiguous means a given codon always codes for the same amino acid. This consistency is essential for accurate protein synthesis.
